notes:
1. Definition of Work

In physics, work is the energy transferred to or from an object by applying a force along a displacement. It is a scalar quantity, measured in Joules (J).

2. Formulas for Work

  • Work by a Constant Force: If a constant force $\b F$ acts on an object that undergoes a displacement $\b d$, the work done by the force is the dot product of the force and displacement vectors.
    • $$W = \b F \cdot \b d = ||\b F|| ||\b d|| \cos(\theta)$$ where $\theta$ is the angle between the force and displacement vectors.
  • Work by a Variable Force: If the force varies as the object moves, the work is calculated by integrating the force component along the path of displacement.
    • $$W = \int_{s_1}^{s_2} F \cos(\theta) ds$$

3. Power

Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. It is a measure of how quickly work can be performed. Power is a scalar quantity.

  • Average Power: The total work done divided by the total time taken. $$\bar{P} = \frac{W}{\Delta t}$$
  • Instantaneous Power: The rate of doing work at a specific moment. It is the derivative of work with respect to time. $$P = \frac{dW}{dt} = \b F \cdot \b v = Fv\cos(\theta)$$

The SI unit of power is the watt (W), where $1 \text{ W} = 1 \text{ Joule/second}$. Another common unit is horsepower (hp), where $1 \text{ hp} \approx 746 \text{ W}$.

4. Efficiency ($\eta$)

The efficiency of a machine or process is the ratio of the useful power output to the total power input. It is a dimensionless quantity, often expressed as a percentage.

$$\eta = \frac{\text{Power out}}{\text{Power in}} = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{in}} = \frac{W_{out}}{W_{in}}$$

Due to energy losses (e.g., from friction, heat), the efficiency is always less than 1 (or 100%). The power lost is $P_{loss} = P_{in} - P_{out}$.

solvedExamples.question: A force of 50 N is applied to a box at an angle of 30° to the horizontal. The box is pushed 10 m along the ground. How much work is done by the applied force?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula for work done by a constant force: $W = Fd\cos(\theta)$.
$W = (50 \text{ N})(10 \text{ m})\cos(30^\circ) = 500 \cdot (\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}) \approx 500 \cdot 0.866 = 433 \text{ J}$.

solvedExamples.question: A crane lifts a 500 kg mass to a height of 20 m in 10 seconds at a constant velocity. What is the average power output of the crane? (Use $g=9.8$ m/s²).
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the work done against gravity: $W = Fd = (mg)d = (500 \text{ kg})(9.8 \text{ m/s²})(20 \text{ m}) = 98,000 \text{ J}$. Then, calculate the average power: $\bar{P} = \frac{W}{\Delta t} = \frac{98,000 \text{ J}}{10 \text{ s}} = 9800 \text{ W}$ or 9.8 kW.

solvedExamples.question: An electric motor has a power input of 5 kW and a useful power output of 4 kW. What is its efficiency?
solvedExamples.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of power out to power in: $\eta = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{in}} = \frac{4 \text{ kW}}{5 \text{ kW}} = 0.8$. To express this as a percentage, multiply by 100: $0.8 \times 100\% = 80\%$.
